awd_titl_txt: “Sustainable Polymers: Physics of New Materials, Design for Sustainability, and End-of-Life”: A DPOLY Short Course at the 2022 American Physical Society Annual Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This conference award will provide partial support for travel expenses of students, postdoctoral researchers, and high school teachers to participate in the Short Course "Sustainable Polymers: Physics of New Materials, Design for Sustainability, and End-of-Life" at the 2022 American Physical Society March Meeting. 
 
This short course will offer the opportunity to advance knowledge in the field of polymer sustainability through instruction from experts and engaging discussions among participants. This short course will bring a focused perspective to this area, with emphasis on physical properties and fundamental physics of polymers and how they may be designed with consideration of sustainability goals and metrics. Towards this goal, researchers will come together from cross-disciplinary areas, including polymer physics, polymer chemistry, and materials science, and address the full life cycle of polymers, from sustainable origins to design for ease of end-of-life handling and re-use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The "Sustainable Polymers: Physics of New Materials, Design for Sustainability, and End-of-Life" short course took place from March 12-13, 2022 at the American Physical Society meeting in Chicago, IL. The topic of polymer sustainability is an urgent one that affects our society globally. The reliance on petroleum resources for polymers and accumulation of plastic waste on land and in waterways lead to harmful environmental impacts. Opportunities such as this short course to bring together experts and educate the next generation of scientists are critical to making progress on addressing these challenges. Topics covered in this short course included fundamental property relationships and processing of sustainable polymers, sustainable syntheses and renewable origins of polymers, reprocessable networks, polymer recycling, upcycling, and degradation, characterization of waste plastics, and life cycle and techno-economic analyses. Attendees gained knowledge on fundamental aspects and cutting edge research in these areas, and experienced tutorial activities for hands-on learning throughout the short course. Presenters at the short course came from academia, industry, and national laboratories. The participants of this short course included graduate students, postdocs, junior and senior faculty members, and junior and senior scientists at national laboratories and in industry. This short course offered important opportunities for young faculty members, students and postdocs to network with senior researchers, and also showcased the research of early career scientists. This award supported travel scholarships for students and high school teachers who participated in the short course.
